title: Tony Johnson ready to prioritize MMA over boxing after viral knockout of Joe Schilling
text:
TEMECULA, Calif. — Tony Johnson has had one hell of a long road to become an overnight sensation.

The 36-year-old San Jose, Calif., native, who also boasts an 8-1 boxing record, has been doing this for quite some time – he competed in Strikeforce all the way back in 2008 – but only now is he starting to get some recognition for his efforts.

Johnson’s wild knockout of kickboxing standout Joe Schilling in the middleweight main-card opener of Bellator 229 on Friday night went viral. And while the clip might be the first you’ve seen of him, that’s in fact five wins in a row for Johnson, who also earned a victory on Dana White’s Contender Series this past summer.

So you can’t blame Johnson, really, for taking a minute to bask in the attention after a long and winding road in the sport, which started way back in 2007.

“Yeah, I gotta say, this makes it feel like all the effort has been worth it,” Johnson told MMA Junkie after the fight. “I’ve been doing this a while, and I’ve been doing it because I love what I do, but it does feel good to get a little bit of recognition.”

Speaking of recognizing, Johnson (8-2 MMA, 1-0 BMMA) seemed to presage the finish late in the first round, when he dropped a hard-charging Schilling (4-6 MMA, 3-3 BMMA), who’s had a tendency to make mental errors, with a wicked counter shot.

From there, the fight turned into a battle of attrition, with Johnson absorbing punishing calf kicks throughout the fight, just to bite down on his mouthpiece and keep moving forward. It also didn’t help that his vision was blurry in one eye for much of the fight.

“I couldn’t see out of one eye, and then I got poked in the other one later,” Johnson said. “It’s not easy to have that guy coming at you when your vision is blurry. Fortunately it cleared itself up by the time the third round started.”

Johnson pressed forward in the third until he landed the fight’s finishing blow, the huge counter left to the jaw that dropped Schilling, followed by one more on the mat just to make sure.

So where does Johnson go from here? He was on a one-fight Bellator deal, which seems to indicate the promotion only expected him to be an “opponent” for Schilling. But with five straight wins and having now proven his ability to put on crowd-pleasing scraps, Johnson has indicated if a real offer comes from Bellator, he’ll prioritize MMA over boxing.

“If Bellator wants to have me around and come to a longer deal, I’ll make it my first priority,” Johnson said. “I love boxing, I still want to do it, but I think I showed people here I can give the type of fights the fans like.”
description: Tony Johnson dropped Joe Schilling with a ridiculous knockout in the third round of their Bellator 229 fight.
